moves.1. c4: Kosten's recipe.  I often want to play something else, but when you start know a system, it has a way of dominating ideas and play.
moves.1... e5 2. g3 d5 3. cxd5 Qxd5 4. Nf3: Not my favorite English opening continuation.  In many ways I think the English as a surefire method for advantage is discredited because of this.  Black can, and often does, challenge white's grip on d5 immediately.
moves.4... e4 5. Nc3 Qc6 6. Ne5: This was somewhat experimental.  The unsupported knight could have gone, more conservatively, to d4 and then if pushed to b3.
moves.6... Qe6 7. Qa4+ Nd7 8. Nxd7 Bxd7 9. Qxe: I really cannot say which side is more purely desirable.
White is better.  See the excellent comment.
A mistake as illustrated by black's next move.
moves.23... Nxe5+: Not only is the pawn pinned, but my king is in check.  It's insult added to injury.
moves.26... Nxb2+: And sees one where there is none.  Finally, a mistake I can capitalize on.
moves.27. Rxb2 Rb8 28. Rc1: With f6 guarded well, I would have, at some point or another in the game, wanted to reposition my rooks.
moves.46. Rb7+ Kc8 47. Rxh7: Knowing the ultimate game result, I think this may be a mistake.
moves.47... Rxa5 48. h4 gxh4 49. Rxh4 Kd7: And here I thought that I had the win in the bag.
moves.50. Rd4+ Ke6: I think the bishop move first was better.
moves.51. Bg2 f5 52. Ke2 Ke5 53. g4 Ra2+ 54. K: Failed to consider that I could not defend both!
moves.57... Rxe3: Clearly a win is possible, but it is not the easy win that I was envisioning.
moves.58. Be4: In a way I'm daring him to go for the win, but if he balks at the effort, I draw.

gameName: One slip and an advantage melts away.
